urn:contentItem:6FGN-9WK3-RRVM-F3XR-00000-00Labor in levy backflip2025-04-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Labor in levy backflipMitch Clarke

The Allan government has been forced to shelve its "bloody wrong" emergency services tax in an embarrassing backflip that will further ignite an already hostile campaign from firefighters, farmers and councils.

The levy - which has been referred to as a "dog of a tax" - will be debated in parliament's upper house on Thursday, but the government won't put the legislation to a vote, as originally planned, because it has failed to secure crossbench support.

Failure to pass the Bill this week means the hostile campaign will now drag out across the federal election campaign, at a time when Jacinta Allan's brand is already causing huge issues for federal Labor.

And with parliament not resuming until April 30, it leaves Treasurer Jaclyn Symes with the prospect of a massive black hole in her first budget, which will be handed down on May 20.

The Allan government is banking on the increased tax, which replaces the existing Fire Services Levy, to rake in an extra $2bn over the forward estimates.

The Herald Sun understands that Ms Symes, who is also the leader of the government in the upper house, has so far been unable to wrangle any crossbench MPs to support the Bill.

Nationals leader and opposition emergency services spokesman Danny O'Brien said it was "great news" that the government didn't have the support to pass the Bill this week.

"This Bill is a massive hit on Victorians during a cost of living crisis," he said.

"We now need the Labor government to realise this was a mistake and withdraw this unfair tax plan altogether." But shadow Treasurer James Newbury said Victorian's "won't be safe from this $2.1bn dollar new tax until Labor scraps the Bill from parliament".

"Labor's shelving of their great big new dog of a tax is only a stay of execution," he said.

Premier Jacinta Allan defended the tax grab and said an increase in natural disasters meant that emergency services needed to be appropriately funded.

"The SES have been calling for these changes," she said.

"Ultimately it's about providing the support to those thousands of volunteers who get out in the worst of circumstances to support us." The government said expanding the tax will support a broader range of emergency services, including the SES, Triple Zero Victoria, State Control Centre, CFA and Forest Fire Management.

But the move has sparked a furious backlash from regional communities who have warned they will be disproportionately impacted by the tax. The Herald Sun on Thursday revealed the peak body that represents rural councils had urged the government to scrap the tax entirely.

urn:contentItem:6FKH-S9D3-RRRW-H4XV-00000-00Fly in, fire out: Rappel firefighting team wraps 40th season2025-04-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisFly in, fire out: Rappel firefighting team wraps 40th season

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Brendan Kearns

Elite rappel firefighters have wrapped their intense 40th fire season, battling blazes with chainsaws and axes as they jump from helicopters.

Hailing from Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) the highly-skilled abseiling firefighters were dispatched more than 50 times since September to combat bushfires in the state, including in the Grampians and Otways.

But as the state's bushfire season wraps up and fire restrictions start to lift the agency is warning that unseasonably warm autumn weather over the Easter long weekend could exacerbate the risk from campfires.

FFMVic chief officer Chris Hardman said his organisation has responded to almost 300 incidents involving campfires this season, including an illegal campfire that sparked the massive Grampians bushfire.

"Campfires that escape are a big problem in Victoria," Mr Hardman said.

He warned that fire pits can rapidly become full-blown bushfires.

While restrictions have started lifting in some parts of the state, they remain in place in many region due to dry autumnal conditions and unpredictable fire behaviour.

FFMVic is the agency responsible for bushfires in state forests and national parks and often directs the response to long-running fires.

Autumn typically gives its crews the chance to conduct planned burns, but dry conditions and strong winds delayed the start to fire management in parts of the state.

The key to FFMVic's strategy is to "keep fires small" which necessitates an "aggressive, thorough and determined" first attack, Mr Hardman said.

But because Victoria has some particularly remote areas such as the Great Dividing Range a rapid response can be difficult for typical vehicle crews.

To combat this the agency operates with rappel firefighters who abseil into the state's remote areas and use chainsaws and hand tools to conduct "dry firefighting".

Mr Hardman said FFMVic firefighters can rapidly respond and aggressively attack emerging bushfires.

"When a fire is detected, they will fly up in a helicopter and they'll drop out of the helicopter on ropes to the forest."

The firefighters will fell dangerous trees with chainsaws and split them open with axes to stop potential bushfires.

Bryan Rees is FFMVic's senior aviation operations officer and has been involved in the program for its full 40 years.

He said that the rappel firefighters are "quiet achievers" as "people don't hear about rappelling much because if the rappellers do their job the fires don't get out".

"There's no big noise about the fires that they work on because they do their job. They get them out and they go home. So the program's been largely overlooked for years because it is very successful."

By getting to fires rapidly the firefighters are able to prevent them growing and spreading said Brodie Leticq, who has been a rappel firefighter for nine seasons.

"That's our main purpose and some of our most challenging fires do come from those remote areas, because you just can't get to them," Mr Leticq said.

"They're not an issue until they are on those bad days. That's what we're there for."

Rappel firefighters are some of the most experienced in the state, all starting as general firefighters before taking to the sky.

FFMVic is ramping up to start recruitment of seasonal firefighters in July, ahead of the next fire season.

urn:contentItem:6FTG-K0M3-RV0X-X45S-00000-00What's all this about a proposed levy?2025-05-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisNEWS3What's all this about a proposed levy?Ben Silvester

Here's how much it will cost you.

The state government will hit rural Victorians with an extra $140 million under the new Emergency Services and Volunteers Levy from July 1.

A financial analysis of 19 councils by Rural Councils Victoria has revealed primary producers will be hit with more than half the extra charges, with some farmers facing $5000 rate hikes.

Further analysis by ACM - publisher of the Addy - showed rural communities will have to pay 50 per cent more than the statewide average as they bear the brunt of the new levy.

RCV chair Rob Amos said the disproportionate hit to rural Victoria was "dreadfully unfair", especially as the government has consistently refused to guarantee the funds will flow evenly back into those communities.

"This new levy will hit Victorian farmers the hardest. How does that make any sense after years of drought and amid a cost-of-living crisis?" Cr Amos said. "At the very least, this new tax burden should be shared equally amongst all Victorian landholders."

The revelations come as Treasurer Jaclyn Symes walked back a guarantee volunteers would be exempt from the new levy. She said all Victorians would be charged the extra amount, with volunteers having to apply for a rebate through the State Revenue Office.

The new ESVL will take effect from July and represents a significant increase on the current Fire Services Property Levy.

The government has said the increased revenue will flow entirely back to Victoria's emergency services but has so far refused to reveal how much more funding these services will get, if any.

RCV collated financial data from 18 rural councils across Victoria to calculate the extra cost of the ESVL compared to the current levy. ACM added data from a further council to the analysis.

ACM had previously revealed four south-west rural councils - Corangamite, Moyne, Glenelg and Southern Grampians - would collectively pay $17.8 million more in 2025-26 because of the new levy.

It found the 19 councils would pay an extra $69,907,940 in 2025-26, or $3,679,365 per council.

If that average holds across the rest of Victoria's 38 rural councils, they will have to pay an additional $139,815,880.

The current levy raises $1,033,000 per year, most of which goes towards running Fire Rescue Victoria (FRV), with the volunteer-driven Country Fire Association also getting a small portion.

The new ESVL will raise $1,649,000 in 2025-26, an increase of $616 million, which allow funding to flow to a broader range of services like the State Emergency Service, Triple Zero Victoria, the State Control Centre, Forest Fire Management Victoria and Emergency Recovery Victoria.

The bill to implement the new levy is currently before parliament and includes a $250 million "support package" for VICSES and CFA. But it's worth noting that FRV's operating costs blew past $1.2 billion in 2023-24, and the government is still unable, or unwilling, to share how much the volunteer services will get. The extra $616 million means the levy will require a 59 per cent increase statewide in 2025-26, but the RCV analysis showed rural councils would be hit with a 90 per cent average increase.

That means rural communities will have to pay 50 per cent more than the statewide average, or $3 for every $2 other Victorians pay.

The government has consistently declined to say whether this disproportionate hit to country Victoria will flow back to rural communities.

Victorian Nationals leader Danny O'Brien said the levy was an illegitimate revenue-raising exercise by the government.

"Victorians are being asked to pay double the amount for core government agencies that have always been paid for by the existing taxes we pay - it's double taxation, pure and simple," Mr O'Brien said.

"The government won't even release a breakdown of how much each of the agencies will receive from this massive new tax impost, and one has to ask why?"

The key change under the ESVL is an increase to the variable rate different property owners will pay on their annual rate bills.

Primary producers will be hit with 83 cents per $1000 of capital improved value, up from just under 29 cents currently.

The RCV analysis showed this change meant farmers across the 18 councils would see their levy spike 154 per cent.

The average farmer in some areas would see their levy triple.

Cr Amos said financial stress was already the second biggest driver of poor mental health for farmers.

"It's going to smash farm budgets, hurt local businesses and cause job losses in our towns and communities," he said.

RCV said it had written to Ms Symes and hoped to sit down with her to discuss the uneven impact of the levy.

"The ESVL isn't scheduled to come into force until July," Cr Amos said.

"There's still time for the Victorian government to acknowledge the inequities and unforeseen consequences of this new levy and make changes."

urn:contentItem:6DTS-MN23-RYVW-M41G-00000-00Racing to save most endangered mammal2025-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Racing to save most endangered mammalAyden Dawkins

Sightings of Victoria's most endangered mammal have sparked hope as communities remain on watch for the devastating Grampians bushfires.

Four southern brush-tailed rock wallabies were sighted by a helicopter during a food drop over the rocky outcrops where they live.

As part of the biodiversity bushfire rapid response, Forest Fire Management Victoria was working to protect remaining key habitat areas and support at-risk biodiversity in the fire-affected areas.

Food and supplement packages containing carrots, sweet potatoes, macropod pellets, and lucerne were dropped at the site.

Grampians National Park area chief ranger Charlie Richardson said the critical focus was on getting food to the colony, with the fires making food sources scarce.

"They can be quite clever in protecting themselves from the initial fire, and that's why it is so critical to get in there as quickly as possible to make sure they have enough food," Mr Richardson said.

Fewer than 100 of the wallabies remain in the wild between the Grampians, where they were reintroduced in 2008 to safeguard from extinction, and east Gippsland.

"The brush-tailed rock wallaby is so endangered largely due to feral pests, predators, foxes, and cats that are devastating the Grampians landscape," Mr Richardson said.

Between 15 and 50 wallabies are believed to be living in the Grampians National Park, he said.

While safety and access to the devastated areas is currently a problem, he said once ground crews deem the areas safe, the rangers will "get in there as well" to sustain a medium and long-term program for the wallabies, "which will be absolutely required".

More than 76,000 hectares have been scorched in the Grampians National Park and Macedon Range.

Forest Fire Management Victoria said no one should enter firegrounds to search for wildlife.

If you find an injured animal impacted by a bushfire, report it to DEECA by calling 136 186 or via wildlife.ffm.vic.gov.au

urn:contentItem:6FJM-TCN3-RVWV-827R-00000-00Melbourne hits hottest April day since 20142025-04-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisMelbourne hits hottest April day since 2014Roy Ward

And the warm weather is set to return later in the week.

Melbourne has experienced its hottest April day since 2014 as the temperature hit 31 degrees on Sunday.

The CBD reached 31 degrees while weather stations at Avalon and Point Cook got to highs of 33 degrees.

Link to Image

Luis Ascui

Bureau of Meteorology senior meteorologist Simon Timcke said Melbourne hadn't experienced an April day this hot since April 1, 2014, and finding a day this hot, this late in April was rare.

"It's the hottest day we have had for a while," Timcke said on Sunday.

"We've got to 31.8 degrees and that's our hottest April day since April 1, 2014, so 11 years since we've seen a day as hot as this in April and that day was the first of the month, to find a day this hot so late in April takes a bit of effort, and we have to go further back in the records.

"We had 32.5 degrees on April 14, 2004, and once we get past mid April, days this hot become a lot less common.

"We got to 33.8 degrees on April 13, 1985, and we got to 34.4 degrees on April 17 back in 1922.

"It's not impossible to get days this hot late in April but it's not very often."

The mercury should come down on Monday to a top of 23 degrees with the possibility of a few showers in the morning.

But Timcke said the weather was forecast to warm up again later in the week as Easter begins.

"We get another high that moves in over the Tasman Sea so the winds go northerly again, and we get a few warmer days towards the end of the week," Timcke said.

Link to Image

Luis Ascui

"It looks like 26 degrees for Tuesday, 29 degrees for Wednesday and Thursday, and then 28 for Friday,

"So we've got a few warmer to finish off the week."

Timcke said the warm weekend was the result of a hot air mass in the north of Victoria.

"We've got a pretty hot air mass over the north of the state, which has been hanging around for a while," Timcke said.

"That along with the high-pressure system getting out of the Tasman Sea, that's directed more northerly winds over us and dragged some of that hot air down from the north because we've had a pretty good run of pretty hot days over the north of the state for a while now.

"So the northerly has just brought some of that hot air down from the north."

Firefighters battled a bushfire four kilometres south-west of Daylesford on Sunday afternoon.

Forest Fire Management Victoria said 72 vehicles and 250 firefighters were fighting the fire that burned through more than 92 hectares of land after it broke out just before 2pm.

A watch and act warning was in place for the communities of Musk Vale, Sailors Falls and Sailors Hill.

Authorities were conducting a planned burn on the Old Tom Track in Hepburn Regional Park on Friday and into the weekend.

Walkers enjoy the warm weather - and autumn leaves - at Melbourne's Botanic Gardens.

The warm weather brought out large numbers of people on The Tan on Sunday.

urn:contentItem:6FJM-TCN3-RVWV-8280-00000-00Melbourne hits hottest April day since 20142025-04-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisMelbourne hits hottest April day since 2014Roy Ward

And the warm weather is set to return later in the week.

Melbourne has experienced its hottest April day since 2014 as the temperature hit 31 degrees on Sunday.

The CBD reached 31 degrees while weather stations at Avalon and Point Cook got to highs of 33 degrees.

Link to Image

Luis Ascui

Bureau of Meteorology senior meteorologist Simon Timcke said Melbourne hadn't experienced an April day this hot since April 1, 2014, and finding a day this hot, this late in April was rare.

"It's the hottest day we have had for a while," Timcke said on Sunday.

"We've got to 31.8 degrees and that's our hottest April day since April 1, 2014, so 11 years since we've seen a day as hot as this in April and that day was the first of the month, to find a day this hot so late in April takes a bit of effort, and we have to go further back in the records.

"We had 32.5 degrees on April 14, 2004, and once we get past mid April, days this hot become a lot less common.

"We got to 33.8 degrees on April 13, 1985, and we got to 34.4 degrees on April 17 back in 1922.

"It's not impossible to get days this hot late in April but it's not very often."

The mercury should come down on Monday to a top of 23 degrees with the possibility of a few showers in the morning.

But Timcke said the weather was forecast to warm up again later in the week as Easter begins.

"We get another high that moves in over the Tasman Sea so the winds go northerly again, and we get a few warmer days towards the end of the week," Timcke said.

Link to Image

Luis Ascui

"It looks like 26 degrees for Tuesday, 29 degrees for Wednesday and Thursday, and then 28 for Friday,

"So we've got a few warmer to finish off the week."

Timcke said the warm weekend was the result of a hot air mass in the north of Victoria.

"We've got a pretty hot air mass over the north of the state, which has been hanging around for a while," Timcke said.

"That along with the high-pressure system getting out of the Tasman Sea, that's directed more northerly winds over us and dragged some of that hot air down from the north because we've had a pretty good run of pretty hot days over the north of the state for a while now.

"So the northerly has just brought some of that hot air down from the north."

Firefighters battled a bushfire four kilometres south-west of Daylesford on Sunday afternoon.

Forest Fire Management Victoria said 72 vehicles and 250 firefighters were fighting the fire that burned through more than 92 hectares of land after it broke out just before 2pm.

A watch and act warning was in place for the communities of Musk Vale, Sailors Falls and Sailors Hill.

Authorities were conducting a planned burn on the Old Tom Track in Hepburn Regional Park on Friday and into the weekend.

urn:contentItem:6DTS-MN23-RYVW-M419-00000-00xxxHope hops: Race to save most endangered mammal from bushfire devastation2025-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1xxxHope hops: Race to save most endangered mammal from bushfire devastationAyden Dawkins

Sightings of Victoria's most endangered mammal have sparked hope as communities remain on watch for the devastating Grampians bushfires.

Four southern brush-tailed rock wallabies were sighted by a helicopter during a food drop over the rocky outcrops where they live.

As part of the biodiversity bushfire rapid response, Forest Fire Management Victoria was working to protect remaining key habitat areas and support at-risk biodiversity in the fire-affected areas.

Food and supplement packages containing carrots, sweet potatoes, macropod pellets, and lucerne were dropped at the site.

Grampians National Park area chief ranger Charlie Richardson said the critical focus was on getting food to the colony, with the fires making food sources scarce.

"They can be quite clever in protecting themselves from the initial fire, and that's why it is so critical to get in there as quickly as possible to make sure they have enough food," Mr Richardson said.

Fewer than 100 of the wallabies remain in the wild between the Grampians, where they were reintroduced in 2008 to safeguard from extinction, and east Gippsland.

"The brush-tailed rock wallaby is so endangered largely due to feral pests, predators, foxes, and cats that are devastating the Grampians landscape," Mr Richardson said.

Between 15 and 50 wallabies are believed to be living in the Grampians National Park, he said.

While safety and access to the devastated areas is currently a problem, he said once ground crews deem the areas safe, the rangers will "get in there as well" to sustain a medium and long-term program for the wallabies, "which will be absolutely required".

More than 76,000 hectares have been scorched in the Grampians National Park and Macedon Range.

Forest Fire Management Victoria said no one should enter firegrounds to search for wildlife.

If you find an injured animal impacted by a bushfire, report it to DEECA by calling 136 186 or via the Wildlife Emergency App at https://wildlife.ffm.vic.gov.au/

urn:contentItem:6F6S-D7X3-RRW4-X1HS-00000-00Hypocrisy of ageing fire trucks2025-02-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 18Hypocrisy of ageing fire trucks

Imagine the uproar if Victorian politicians and public servants were told to drive around in 20 to 30-year-old Toyota Corollas and Commodores, with wind-up windows, no airconditioning or airbags, nor Bluetooth connectivity.

Yet CFA volunteers are expected to drive into danger in 743 trucks that are more than 20 years old, including 230 that are 30-35 years old.

What's worse is that 870 of the CFA's tankers are single-cab vehicles that force half the crew to ride on the back of the truck, in the open air. It's not just the hypocrisy of the government that fires up volunteers, it's that Premier Allan and Treasurer Jaclyn Symes are putting volunteers' lives at risk.

Both seem to have forgotten their regional roots, given they could easily deliver the $55m a year the CFA needs to replace all trucks after 20 years of service. The government recently rebadged the Fire Services Property Levy as an Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund, increasing the amount collected from households and businesses from $1.033bn this financial year to $1.649bn in 2025-26 and $1.8bn in 2026-27.

The bulk of the extra $616m in extra 2025-26 levy revenue will go straight into funding Triple Zero Victoria, the State Control Centre, Emergency Management Victoria, Emergency Recovery Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria. Just $50m a year will go towards the CFA, VicSES and other emergency service volunteers.

The CFA will get an extra $10m a year for truck upgrades, well short of the $55m needed. The facts are that volunteers are paying the price of Melbourne's big-build blowouts and a government interest bill that sits at $6.6bn this financial year alone.

urn:contentItem:6FDR-K8G3-S2H4-5341-00000-00Firey bugbears slam comms2025-03-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Firey bugbears slam commsRACHEL SIMMONDS

Crucial hours lost, fewer strategic burns and a "severe lack" of communication are Victorian volunteer firefighters' brewing concerns amid calls for change in the management of the state's response to bushfire.

Regional communities are hosting meetings across Victoria following the Little Desert and Grampians National Park fires, to air their grievances about statewide fire management.

Dimboola farmer Simon Nuske said there was a "severe lack of communication" between state management and rural fire brigades, adding he was lucky to be forewarned about the recent fire's severity by a friend.

"It could have been a lot different," he told a Winiam Hall meeting last week. "I could've lost all my sheds, but I was out there fighting on my block. "It gave me time to do my things and put my things in place, but it could've saved other people too." CFA volunteer Mark Colbert was part of the Little Desert National Park firefighting efforts on January 27, and said there needed to be more strategic burn-offs and better communication.

"The best part of the day, we are not active," he said.

"We get nothing done between daybreak and midday because of meetings, we cannot go and act on our own directives.

"We must have DEECA approval, we cannot move.

"Some days there are hours lost in those critical times," he said. "That has to be my biggest operational bugbear." Rainbow's Tony Clark, who is also a police officer in the township, said he hoped to see emergencies better streamlined.

"I've worked in (the incident centre) on the police side, and it's just been a bloody nightmare," he said.

Meeting chairman and Lawloit farmer John Bennett said there were past meetings between senior fire authorities and rural brigades about the Little Desert's management.

"Those guys had intimate knowledge of their environment in the scrub â€¦ Is that still happening?" he said.

Lowan Nationals MP Emma Kealy, Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA representatives will meet at Willaura Memorial Hall on Wednesday to review the Grampians National Park fire.

Grampians Asset Protection group secretary and Howitt Society president Peter Flinn said the meeting would call for more effective and timely fire prevention, with broadscale fuel reduction and firebreak rehabilitation.

"Obviously, rapid suppression is vital in dangerous fire weather, but a response-only strategy, as favoured by some environmentalists, would be disastrous," Mr Flinn said. "In particular, the path of the Yarram Gap fire was eerily similar to that of 2006 in so many ways, and it begs the question as to whether we have learnt from history."

Regional communities are hosting meetings across Victoria following the Little Desert and Grampians National Park fires, to air their grievances about statewide fire management.

urn:contentItem:6F7M-WCT3-RWNM-02JG-00000-00Strathbogie Ranges fire burns through 550ha, residents told to leave2025-03-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisStrathbogie Ranges fire burns through 550ha, residents told to leaveBy Gaye Pattison and Andrew Kelso

Authorities say the fire has burnt through 550 hectares of bushland, and smoke is visible from the Hume Freeway and Euroa.

Firefighters continue to battle a bushfire in the Strathbogie Ranges in Victoria's north east. 

A watch and act message remains in place for the communities of Baddaginnie, Boho, Boho South, Marraweeney and Warrenbayne.

An advice message has also been issued for Balmattum, Benalla, Creek Junction, Lima, Lima East, Swanpool and Violet Town.

Authorities said the fire has burnt through 550 hectares of bushland, with smoke visible from the Hume Freeway and Euroa.

No properties are known to have been impacted, but the official warning says that preparing to leavenow is "strongly recommended".

Aircraft conducted water-bombing operations overnight, while more than 100 firefighters from Forest Fire Management, the Country Fire Authority and HPV plantation company worked to control the blaze on the ground.  

Bureau of meteorology senior meteorologist Lincoln Trainor says smoke is visible on the satellite.

"It's a narrow plume moving to the north, you may see some smoke haze if you are in the area," he said.

Mr Trainor said a southerly wind moved in yesterday at 25-35 kilometres an hour with gusts up to 50 kilometres during the night.

This gave the fire favourable conditions to spread.

These conditions are likely to occur this afternoon but will ease.

"Fresh southerly winds will ease overnight, into tomorrow and we will see another surge ahead of Monday before winds become lighter during Tuesday," he said.

Incident controller Scott Edwards said the main priorities today will be attacking the fire directly with aircraft, and keeping it away from Kay's Track to avoid the blaze reaching adjoining pine plantations. 

Dozers, excavators and harvesters have also been building containment lines. 

The cause of the fire is still being investigated.

urn:contentItem:6FC7-T2S3-RRS7-G40X-00000-00Services tax slug 'immoral'2025-03-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Services tax slug 'immoral'Peter Hunt

The Allan Government is about to slug Traynors Lagoon CFA brigade's 14 farming families with a $212,500 emergency services tax bill from July 1.

The Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund tax is almost triple the $73,500 the brigade paid in fire services property levies this financial year.

Treasurer Jaclyn Symes said CFA and VicSES volunteers can claim an ESVF rebate on up to $5m of their farmland - about $4150 per farm, which still leaves the brigade facing a $154,000 tax bill or $11,000 per family.

Brigade captain Jason Barratt said at the end of the day "we're paying a lot more for the privilege of fighting our own fires".

"We won't see better services. We're just paying for a lot of public servants," he said.

The brigade has a 36-year-old tanker, which Mr Barratt said could easily be replaced with a more modern second-hand model for a third of what its volunteers would pay in ESVF tax.

But rather than supporting CFA brigades Premier Jacinta Allan and her Treasurer Jaclyn Symes will use the extra funds to plug their budgetary holes.

The government will rake in an extra $616m under the new tax, lifting its take from $1.033bn in FSPL this financial year to $1.649bn under the ESVF in 2025-26.

However just $50m of the extra tax take will go towards boosting CFA, VicSES, Surf Live Saving Victoria and community coast guard volunteers funding.

Legislation introduced to parliament earlier this month allows the government to use the ESVF tax to fund up to 95 per cent of Triple Zero Victoria, the State Control Centre, Emergency Management Victoria, Emergency Recovery Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Traynors Lagoon volunteer Colin Coates said what the government was doing was "immoral".

"This Labor Government doesn't appreciate us, because they're taxing us to the hilt and we can't counter it." He said many "people don't realise what's going on" and won't until their 2025-26 rates bill arrives.

Traynors Lagoon volunteer, farmer and local accountant Peter Knights said the brigade's 14 farming families owned about 32,000ha, worth about $8000/ha. Given the new ESVF rate for farmland will be set at 83 cents per $1000 of capital improved value, the brigade's members will pay about $212,500 on a total CIV of $256m. The estimate does not include the $276 fixed charge each farm must also pay.

urn:contentItem:6F58-M1W3-RS1W-T0JC-00000-00Reduction burns key in fire fight2025-02-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Reduction burns key in fire fightALEX SINNOTT

More fuel reduction burns are needed across regional Victoria to ease the burden on rural firefighters, a former CSIRO division chief says.

Retired forestry bureaucrat Glen Kile says Victoria's 'detection and suppression' approach to bushfire management had frustrated efforts to control large-scale fires, including the recent Grampians bushfire which scorched 22,000ha - double the size of Hong Kong.

Dr Kile has previously served as CSIRO Forestry and Forest Products chief and later as executive director of the Forest and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation.

Writing in today's edition of The Weekly Times, Dr Kile said fuel reduction burning was "an essential land management practice in Victoria's fire-prone environment".

"We need more mild fire in the landscape, not less," he said. Dr Kile, who is a member of the Order of Australia for service to forest science, said the recent Los Angeles fires were a cautionary lesson for Victoria.

"Advocates of a response-only strategy over-estimate the effectiveness of aerial water and fire retardant dropping as means of fire suppression," he said.

Victorian Environment Minister Steve Dimopoulos was contacted by The Weekly Times for comment.

Mr Dimopoulos' office deferred to the Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action.

A DEECA spokeswoman said: "Forest Fire Management Victoria and our emergency sector partners work hard to reduce bushfire risk all year round.

"Our approach is underpinned by evidence, local knowledge and continuous improvement - thereby ensuring that our efforts are directed where they will have the greatest impact," the DEECA spokeswoman said. " Firefighters will pay price for misguided strategy, Page 18

urn:contentItem:6FC8-N153-RSR8-502F-00000-00'We're paying a lot more for the privilege of fighting our own fires'2025-03-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexis'We're paying a lot more for the privilege of fighting our own fires'

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Peter Hunt

The Allan Government is about to slug Traynors Lagoon CFA brigade's 14 farming families with a $212,500 emergency services tax bill from July 1.

The Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund tax is almost triple the $73,500 the brigade paid in fire services property levies this financial year.

Treasurer Jaclyn Symes said CFA and VicSES volunteers can claim a ESVF rebate on up to $5m of their farmland - about $4150 per farm, which still leaves the brigade facing a $154,000 tax bill or $11,000 per family.

Brigade captain Jason Barratt said at the end of the day "we're paying a lot more for the privilege of fighting our own fires".

"We won't see better services. We're just paying for a lot of public servants," he said.

The brigade has a 36-year-old tanker, which Mr Barratt said could easily be replaced with a more modern second-hand model for a third of what its volunteers would pay in ESVF tax.

But rather than supporting CFA brigades Premier Jacinta Allan and her Treasurer Jaclyn Symes will use the extra funds to plug their budgetary holes.

The government will rake in an extra $616m under the new tax, lifting its take from $1.033bn in FSPL this financial year to $1.649bn under the ESVF in 2025-26.

However just $50m of the extra tax take will go towards boosting CFA, VicSES, Surf Live Saving Victoria and community coast guard volunteers funding.

Legislation introduced to Parliament earlier this month allows the government to use the ESVF tax to fund up to 95 per cent of Triple Zero Victoria, the State Control Centre, Emergency Management Victoria, Emergency Recovery Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Traynors Lagoon volunteer Colin Coates said what the government was doing was "immoral".

"This Labor Government doesn't appreciate us, because they're taxing us to the hilt and we can't counter it."

He said many "people don't realise what's going on" and won't until their 2025-26 rates bill arrives.

Traynors Lagoon volunteer, farmer and local accountant Peter Knights said the brigades 14 farming families owned about 32,000ha, worth about $8000/ha.

Given the new ESVF rate for farmland will be set at 83 cents per $1000 of capital improved value, the brigade's member will pay about $212,500 on a total CIV of $256m.

The estimate does not include the $276 fixed charge each farm must also pay.

urn:contentItem:6F7D-M143-RTPM-Y1VG-00000-00Levy raises questions2025-02-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisLevy raises questionsMichelle Dorian,Tarrangower Times

A State Government levy to raise funds for emergency services has caused some concerns, with suggestions that there was not enough consultation and that the levy is an expanded tax.

The Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund (ESVF) was announced in December by the Victorian Government as a replacement for the Fire Services Property Levy and will be collected from Tuesday 1 July. The Government stated that the levy will provide funding for emergency services including VICSES, Triple Zero Victoria, the State Control Centre, Emergency Management Victoria, Emergency Recovery Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria, in addition to the CFA and Fire Rescue Victoria. Active CFA and VICSES volunteers and life members will be eligible for an exemption from paying the ESVF on their primary place of residence and the ESVF will be collected by councils and appear on rates notices.

Questions have been raised during last week’s parliamentary question time and in press releases from the Nationals, who said that the levy created less transparency on where and how money is spent. The Nationals’ Member for Northern Victoria Gaelle Broad said: “The ESVF is an expanded tax which will be collected by local councils.” She accused the government of scrambling to adequately fund vital emergency services through the ESVF. “This forces Victorian ratepayers to foot the bill for what should be core government services,” Ms Broad said.

Meanwhile Rural Councils Victoria (representing 34 member councils across the state) stated that it is “…disappointed with both a lack of consultation and the changes themselves, which are unfair on rural councils and rural communities.” RCV says it has written to state government ministers to seek clarity and about how the levy can be delivered fairly and equitably.

Further information on the ESVF is available at tinyurl.com/mvs4bcz5.

urn:contentItem:6FW6-2033-RSD2-D17R-00000-00Already struggling with drought, fire levy pushes farmers to the brink2025-05-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Already struggling with drought, fire levy pushes farmers to the brinkBenjamin Preiss | Regional Editor

In the midday sun, Stuart Green stands in a barren paddock at his farm in north-eastern Victoria gazing at clouds of dust rising behind the flock of sheep streaming towards him.

Ordinarily, his property in Benalla would be flush with grass at this time of year. Instead, it's unseasonably warm. And dry.

"We're really struggling as a small farming enterprise," he said. "You talk to people that have been around for a long time, and they haven't seen it this hard and this dry."

There is not even a hint of grass growth for his sheep to eat. But in addition to buying in feed for his animals, Green is facing other rising costs, too.

The most contentious of them is the new Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund - a levy imposed by the state government. From July, it will replace the Fire Services Property Levy, which property owners paid to help fund the Country Fire Authority and Fire Rescue Victoria.

The new levy will go towards all emergency services, and many farmers are facing a 150 per cent increase. Green estimates his levy will increase from about $1000 to $2500.

This confluence of drought and a marked increase in the levy brought crowds of irate farmers and CFA volunteers to a noisy protest on the steps of state parliament this week while the Victorian government handed down its budget inside.

The Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund applies to owners across property sectors, including residential, commercial and industrial. But the rate of increase for farmers is among the steepest.

Parts of western Victoria are currently in the grip of a record-breaking drought. In about 25 local government areas, farmers are eligible for drought infrastructure grants of up to $5000, although they require a dollar-for-dollar contribution from the grant recipient.

Farmers in those 25 municipalities are also eligible for partial rebates on their emergency services levies this year. But farmers in north-east Victoria, including Stuart Green, are ineligible for the partial levy rebate and drought infrastructure grants.

He says that decision is impossible to understand, given nearby towns of Euroa and Violet Town will be placed on water restrictions next week.

Green has run out of rainwater even though he has a vast network of tanks with a 120,000-litre capacity. He says the state government's refusal to acknowledge his community with additional support has added to his family's frustrations.

"We're just absolutely sick of dust. You can't deny it's dry."

The Nationals MP for Euroa, Annabelle Cleeland, has started a petition that now has more than 4600 signatures urging the state government to declare a drought in north-eastern Victoria, so farmers there can also access support.

She said it defied belief farmers in her community were unable to access the same level of support as primary producers in other parts of the state.

"What I'm most concerned about is, farmers are at breaking point," she said.

A government spokesman said Agriculture Victoria was providing farmers business and technical decision-making support across the state, included in its $29.4million drought support package.

"We continue to back farmers impacted by drought and dry conditions across the state with expanded support for farmers," he said. "We are monitoring conditions across the state to ensure we're offering tailored support to farmers when and where they need it."

The government insists the money raised through the fund will support Victoria's emergency services. It also says most CFA and State Emergency Service volunteers will be better off under the changes.

Those volunteers can claim a rebate on the levy, which can apply to their farm or principal place of residence.

The government is expanding the levy so it covers other emergency services, including the State Emergency Service, triple zero, Forest Fire Management Victoria and other services.

The levy is imposed in two parts: a fixed charge and a variable charge. The fixed charge on farming properties will increase only from $267 to $275. However, the variable charge for primary production land will rise from 28.7¢ per $1000 of the property's capital improved value to 71.8¢.

Rural Councils Victoria chair Rob Amos said even the name of the levy was misleading.

"It's not a fund," he said. "It's not even about volunteers. It's just a tax increase."

Amos said farmers would be hit the hardest by the increases, which came at a time when many were struggling with higher costs and the drought. He said local communities would suffer.

"We're in a cost-of-living crisis," he said. "Every dollar sent to Spring Street is a dollar we can't spend in our communities."

It will fall to councils to collect the new levy. Amos said councils would probably have to deal with frustration over the levy from property owners.

Many CFA volunteers have threatened to walk away from the emergency service and some have hung their uniforms on farm fences in protest. Local councils have also pushed back against the charge.

On Friday last week, the CFA's acting chief officer, Garry Cook, acknowledged some crews were unavailable overnight due to "crewing issues". Those issues stemmed from anger over the levy.

Cook said volunteers and brigades had experienced a long summer of fire activity in addition to pressure from the drought.

"We respect their rights to engage in matters relevant to their local communities, including those who are concerned about the potential impact of the Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund," he said.

A spokesman for the Victorian SES said how emergency services were funded was a matter for the state government. But he noted the SES and volunteers had been advocating for more support in response to the increasing demands of floods, storms and rescues.

"Many VICSES volunteers have shared that, on top of training and responding to emergencies, they spend countless hours fundraising in their communities to operate their units," the spokesman said.

Victorian Farmers Federation president Brett Hosking said he was facing an increase in the levy from about $12,000 to $20,000. "It's a massive hit," he said.

News of the increased cost had come at a terrible time, Hosking said, with farmers across much of the state struggling to run their businesses. "We know our yield potentially reduces every time we wait another week for rain."

RMIT emeritus professor of public policy, David Hayward, said the new levy would raise an additional $600 million, bringing the total to $1.6 billion next year.

He said the fire services levy was introduced more than 10 years ago in response to a recommendation from the bushfire royal commission following Black Saturday.

"It was done on the value of the property and the land, which was deemed to be the fairest way of striking the tax," Hayward said.

But Hayward said maintaining the cost of running emergency services was increasing with climate change resulting in more extreme weather.

In north-eastern Victoria, farmers are now looking to the skies in hope. But Stuart Green's wife, Julie, said even if it rained consistently now, it would still take months for the grass to grow.

"We're hoping and praying for rain because this has got to come into a hay crop in October," she said.

urn:contentItem:6F7X-PK13-RRWD-W0FY-00000-00Firefighters condemn thieves after car found torched in bush near Ballarat2025-03-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisFirefighters condemn thieves after car found torched in bush near BallaratAdam Spencer

A late-model Toyota Prado had been dumped and set on fire.

Police are appealing for information following yet another vehicle theft and arson in the Ballarat region.

Firefighters, including the Glen Park and Invermay CFA brigades and Forest Fire Management Victoria crews, were called to James Hill Road in the Glen Park State Forest about 5.15pm on Friday, February 28.

They found what is believed to be a late-model Toyota Landcruiser Prado on fire, with the blaze spreading into bushland.

Further investigations were expected to take place over the weekend.

In a social media post, the Glen Park Fire Brigade condemned those responsible.

"Unfortunately this is another example of the complete disregard of these thieves for public safety and private property," it said.

About 30 minutes later, firefighters and police were then called to a home on Geelong Road, Canadian after reports of a fire behind some properties.

When firefighters arrived, they saw a backyard fence on fire which spread to nearby trees and shrubs.

Police said the occupants from neighbouring properties were evacuated, with the fire quickly contained.

Witnesses told police they saw three people running from the scene into parkland near the fire.

Anyone with information on either incident are urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or submit a confidential report online at crimestoppersvic.com.au

It comes as much of the Ballarat region r   emains tinder-dry , with little rainfall over summer. Authorities are urging residents to not be complacent about bushfire safety just because the end of summer has passed.

The Australian Seasonal Bushfire Outlook for Autumn forecasts large parts of western and central Victoria, as well as south and west Gippsland, face an increased risk of fire in early autumn.

Need more news from The Courier? Follow our WhatsApp channel for the latest stories, or download our app for the fastest access to our news, Today's Paper and puzzles.

urn:contentItem:6FND-V253-RRV4-M06X-00000-00ANATOMY OF A FIRE2025-04-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 17ANATOMY OF A FIRE

For three weeks over this past Christmas period, the Grampians burned. Here is how it unfolded.

Day One - December 17

A fire flared near the hamlet of Mirranatwa around lunchtime, but nearby aircraft worked with ground crews to suppress it. A second blaze was spotted further east across the Grampians Road; two Air Tractor AT-802As and forest firefighters helped constrain it. Later, a third fire started in even more inaccessible terrain.

A prized large air tanker - a Q400AT - arrived from Avalon about 4pm after first tackling a fire in far south-west Victoria, according to flight data. But it could not suppress this blaze, which quickly jumped Yarram Gap Road.

Day Two - December 18

The fire pushed west, triggering an emergency warning for Mirranatwa (population 31) and forcing campers to evacuate.

Burning through dry and inaccessible terrain, the fire was too big to put out with water drops, Forest Fire Management Victoria deputy incident controller Glenn Rudolph says.

Day Three - December 19

A specialised observation helicopter with a heat-sensing camera helped authorities decide to downgrade warnings for Mirranatwa about 9am. Helicopters - "Helitaks" - and planes worked the fire edge, while crews backburned further north as wind picked up and a total fire ban was declared for the next day.

Day Four - December 20

Hot north-west winds fanned the flames, creating a giant smoke plume that drifted over Melbourne. Rudolph remembers: "This is when it went from a large fire to a really large fire."

A wind change pushed the blaze out of dense bushland in the mid-afternoon and it headed for Halls Gap. Rudolph says computer modelling considered it only an "outside chance" for flames to reach the town that night. But the bush was drier than anyone had realised, and the fire front soon entered a valley where strong wind funnelled it. The planes had to stop because smoke, wind and turbulence made flying too dangerous.

The fire reached Lake Bellfield and an emergency "leave now" warning was issued for Halls Gap. The blaze had almost tripled to 30,000 hectares and travelled

16 kilometres in a single day.

Day Five - December 21

As Halls Gap was evacuated, fire tongues approached either side of Lake Bellfield, forcing firefighters to scramble to build new control lines. "This is where the aircraft became really useful," Rudolph says. "We had Helitaks ... drawing out of the lake. Their turnaround time was like a minute, and they just dropped thousands and thousands of litres of water on those northern parts of the fire. You'd like to think they would put the fire out, but when things are that dry, all they do is hold it."

Many aircraft operated at low altitude in mountainous terrain, obstructing some flight-tracking.

Day Six - December 22

Large air tankers tackled inaccessible flames further south as ground crews, small AirTractor planes, and helicopters fought fires near Halls Gap and Pomonal.

Day Seven - December 23

Smaller aircraft from Hamilton patrolled the fire's southern edge near Dunkeld ahead of forecast northerly wind. Large planes made firebombing runs near Halls Gap as spot fires threatened.

Day Eight - Christmas Eve

"The fire broke out a bit to the east near Mount William," Rudolph says. "Then we were trying to set ourselves up for the next spike in weather over Christmas and Boxing Day."

Day Nine - Christmas Day

Ahead of near-catastrophic conditions for Boxing Day, authorities called upon extra aircraft, including a C130 Hercules, owned by Canada's Coulson Aviation and contracted to the federal government's smaller national fleet.

Further south, aircraft tried to contain activity near Bornes Hill.

As Rudolph says: "With those bad winds coming, that was definitely going to be putting Dunkeld under some threat."

Day 10 - Boxing Day

More than 1000 firefighters focused on the Grampians fire. Hot north-west winds caused the blaze to break out into eastern paddocks near Mafeking.

CFA crews raced to douse the flames in open farmland, but Rudolph says: "The aircraft had to be stood down for a period during the day just because the conditions were too extreme."

Authorities worried about Moyston and Willaura as a south-west wind change hit in the evening.

The shift was not as bad as feared, but the fire had burnt 13,000 hectares more since lunchtime.

Day 11 - December 27

Easing conditions allowed air tankers to make bombing runs and smaller aircraft to assess the damage that ran to 75,000 burnt hectares and four lost properties.

Near Halls Gap, a "mineral earth line" was built on the fire's northern edge. Bulldozers cleared vegetation on flatter ground while firefighters scaled a cliff to clear less accessible bush by hand and set up sprinklers.

Days 12-15 - December 28-30

Easing weather conditions and rough terrain blunted the fire's spread. Small aircraft were still running but no large air tankers.

Day 21 - January 6

After control lines held on a weekend with elevated temperatures, authorities declared the fire contained.

urn:contentItem:6DNN-2PT1-DY47-5435-00000-00Leave now warnings issued for bushfires at Hotspur, Grampians National Park2024-12-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisLeave now warnings issued for bushfires at Hotspur, Grampians National ParkBy Laura Mayers and Eden Hynninen

Water-bombing aircraft have been called in to fight two out-of control bushfires, with a leave now message issued for nearby communities.

Water-bombing aircraft have been called in to fight two out-of control bushfires in far south-west Victoria. 

A bushfire in the Hotspur State Forest is travelling in a north-easterly direction near pine plantations. 

Twenty CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria crews are working on the ground to control the blaze, alongside seven aerial water-bombers.

A CFA spokesperson said crews had worked hard to contain the fire to the state forest.

A leave now alert has been issued, and people are urged to evacuate from the area.

A similar alert has been issued for Mafeking in the Gariwerd/Grampians north of Dunkeld, where seven Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMV) crews and six aircraft are working to fight the fire, which is contained to the Gariwerd/Grampians National Park.

A smaller blaze is also being fought to the south at Brady Swamp by FFMV crews.

The new evacuation messages come as a bushfire that ignited near Creswick, north of Ballarat, in scorching temperatures and high winds yesterday, remains at advice level. 

The fire burned through nearly 200 hectares of the Creswick State Forest at 5pmafter the temperature in the area reached 41 degrees.

It is believed about a dozen residents around Creswick, including at a campground near the forest, were evacuated to a relief centre.

Up to 250 Forest Fire Management and CFA personnel worked quickly to attend the fire, which is still not under control.

Residents in the townships of Dean, Wattle Park, Clarkes Hill, and Newlyn have been urged to stay informed while crews are still at the fire ground.

Forest Fire Management Incident Controller Jon Rofe told the ABC fire investigators and Victoria Police were at the fire ground trying to determine how the blaze began.

He said there were no reports of house or shed losses but crews were continuing to assess properties.

Warm weather warning

Mr Rofe urged residents across the state to stay vigilant and prepared ahead of more warm weather at the end of the week. 

This includes continuing to look out for warnings and to mitigate fuel and hazards that could prevent fire trucks from accessing properties. 

"Thursday and Friday gets up into the low 30s — one good thing about that is that we won't have the extreme winds that we had yesterday," Mr Rofe said.

"But it still will increase the chance of fire danger of course."

Mr Rofe said crews on the scene of the Creswick fire were focusing on assessing hazardous trees.

"One of the key tasks today is blacking out — putting out the trees and the stumps on the fireground," he said.

Residents recount evacuation

Creswick residents said they were prepared to flee, but were relieved when a cool change moved the fire away from the town of about 3,000 people.

"About 5 o'clock I heard the fire siren go — I got my emergency things packed up, and spent the evening listening to the phone," resident Frances Fiddian said.

"The phone [went off] all night — but I'm really glad to see that things seem so much better today.

"I'm hoping this is it, but I'm pretty sure it won't be. So I guess we are just going to have to be prepared and hope that it really rains."

Northern New South Wales resident Brennan James Armfield was camping near Creswick State Forest when the fire started.

"We just saw thick black smoke coming through the hills, and we knew it was time to go," he said.

"We left some belongings there … we will probably have to go back there tomorrow.

"I've been through a few fires before … it was pretty dry [in the forest]. But this is just part of living in Australia, you have to be observant and aware of your surroundings."

Sarah Russell was evacuated to a relief centre in Creswick, and told the ABC she had been living at a campground near the forest. 

"We've been living down at Slaty Creek campground one in our camper," Ms Russell said.

"It's been a bit hot — we came into town to cool off at the water park … went back and we saw fire, flames and smoke.

"There was this lovely local, she came down with her family, her car and her trailer, and she just helped us pack our things in … and we were the last ones to leave."

Ms Russell said she kept an eye on the Vic Emergency map and watched as the fire was upgraded to an emergency level around 6:30pm. 

"Our car temperature reached 44 degrees. CFA were lovely, they came over to inspect everyone's [camp] fires and make sure they were out."

The relief centre in Creswick remains open today.

urn:contentItem:6F9S-1093-S153-N506-00000-00Rebate sells fireys short2025-03-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Rebate sells fireys shortPETER HUNT

Many Victorian farmers who are CFA and VicSES volunteers will still be worse off under the Allan government's new Emergency Services Volunteer Fund tax, despite being able to claim refunds of up to $4150.

Treasurer Jaclyn Symes said farmers who were volunteers could apply for an exemption on paying the tax, which comes in on July 1, on property worth up to $5m in capital improved value.

Under the current Fire Services Property Levy, farmers paid 28.7c per $1000 of their property's CIV this financial year.

But under the new ESVF property tax farmers will pay 83c/$1000 of CIV in 2025-26 - a three-fold increase.

It means a typical $15m Victorian farm, which paid $4305 in FSPL levies this financial year, faces paying $12,450 in 2025-26.

If that same property owner is a CFA or VicSES volunteer they can apply to the State Revenue Office for a maximum rebate of $4150, which still leaves them with an ESVF tax bill of $8300 - almost twice what they paid under the FSPL.

Victorian Farmers Federation president and CFA volunteer Brett Hosking said triple the levy would hurt all Victorians. As for the rebate, Mr Hosking said: "It's just wrong for many volunteers to be still funding a service they have to provide." Volunteer Fire Brigades Victoria chief executive Adam Barnett said the government was yet to consult the group's members, which was a statutory obligation.

Even with the rebate, Mr Barnett said volunteers were concerned about the impact of the new tax on their communities.

"People can't afford it and the government has underestimated the pain communities are feeling," he said.

Under the FSPL the government generated $1.033bn in 2024-25 levy revenue, but the ESVF will lift its tax take to $1.649bn in 2025-26 and $1.8bn in 2026-27.

However, just $50m of the $616m in extra revenue the government gains in the new financial year will go towards supporting CFA, VicSES, Surf Live Saving Victoria and community coast guard volunteers.

Instead, the ESVF legislation, introduced to parliament this week, opens the door for the government to use the tax to fund up to 95 per cent of Triple-0 Victoria, the State Control Centre, Forest Fire Management Victoria, Emergency Management Victoria and other agencies. Ms Symes said: "We're making sure our emergency services have the sustainable funding and equipment they need to keep Victorians safe and to recover from natural disasters."

urn:contentItem:6FPH-0B83-RSWK-50VP-00000-00'It's money I haven't got': Farmers raise concerns about new levy2025-05-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexis'It's money I haven't got': Farmers raise concerns about new levyNieve Walton Isobel Cootes

'They're starting to think: how the hell am I gonna pay that?'

The more Victorian farmers learn about a new emergency services levy, the more "they're starting to think, 'How the hell am I gonna pay that?'"

With some rural properties facing a $5000 rate hike because of the new levy, regional residents will be paying attention to Spring Street on May 13 when parliament returns.

The controversial Emergency Services and Volunteers Levy has faced backlash from councils , Rural Councils Victoria, the firefighters' union, and the Victorian Farmers Federation.

"They're not the sort that are normally all on the same page," Victorian Nationals leader Danny O'Brien told The Courier.

"That should tell the government that they've got this wrong."

The state government has proposed an up to 189 per cent increase in the variable component of the levy for primary production land from July 1.

The existing levy raises $1,033,000 per year.

The new levy is anticipated to raise an additional $610.9 million in the 2025/26 financial year, and a further $765 million in the following two years.

The new levy will pay for nine emergency services: the State Emergency Service (SES), Triple Zero, the State Control Centre, Forest Fire Management Victoria, Emergency Recovery Victoria, Emergency Management Victoria, other emergency programs, the Country Fire Authority (CFA), and Fire Rescue Victoria (FRV).

About 150 people attended a community forum last month in Beaufort about it, and on Tuesday night, it was a similar story at the Ascot Hall.

Clunes sheep farmer, Stuart Robinson, was tasked with making sure the community knew about the levy and its implications.

But, he said, even though it was being promoted as a volunteer support fund, it only benefited two such organisations.

A total of $50 million per year has been earmarked for CFA and SES.

"There's only two volunteer organisations in those nine bodies, that being the CFA and the SES. Regions and towns won't see any of that, or very little of that money, come back," Mr Robinson said.

"It's going to really impact our region. As they become aware of it, they're starting to think, 'How the hell am I gonna pay that?'. It has nothing to do with productivity. It has nothing to do with improving your farm. It's just a straight-out tax.

"A 500-hectare farm in the City of Ballarat that's worth $25,000 a hectare is going to cost them $10,500. And that's on top of their rates. The really hard part about it is that a couple of years ago, it was $1800 to $2000."

Fellow farmer John Henderson-Drife said the younger generation was very worried and pointed to the ramifications for the wider community.

"The awareness is coming, but it's coming a bit too late," he said.

"I've had younger farmers say, 'Well, it's money I haven't got for a start, and then it's money I won't have to spend in the community'.

"Not only that, the state government has put it on councils to be the collectors and the administrators, which is going to cost them a lot of money."

In February, the City of Ballarat council's mayor, Tracey Hargreaves, said the change raised "considerable concerns that must be addressed".

Adding it would "place an undue financial burden on all " in the city.

The council estimated, on average, farmers in the electorate would be hit with a 122 per cent increase.

While commercial ratepayers would see an estimated 75 per cent increase, an estimated 47 per cent increase for industrial land, and homeowners could expect a 29 per cent increase, on average.

The state government, however, claims the levy is essential to deliver frontline emergency services.

Amid dry weather conditions and American tariff uncertainty , Mr O'Brien said regional communities were already doing it tough.

"Even if things were going well, it would be a big hit on many farmers, as it is on every household in the state," he said.

"This is not just impacting the farming community; the new rates for this emergency services levy will double for every residence in Victoria."

As part of the state government's $50m yearly budget, the SES is set to receive $25 million and the CFA will get $10m for new fleets, while the remaining $15m will go towards the Volunteer Emergency Services Equipment Program (VESEP).

VESEP grants allow volunteer groups to purchase equipment, with $2 for every $1 raised matched by the grants up to a maximum of $150,000.

"If the funds go ahead, it will come up on your rates notice as the emergency service and volunteers fund," Mr Robinson said.

"So people will see that, and when we try to raise money for new equipment, they're going to be a bit jaded. They'll think, 'Well, we're already contributing'. So I've got concerns about fundraising efforts in future too."

There will be limited respite for regional communities, with active emergency volunteers and life members exempt from the new levy for their primary place of residence.

The emergency services levy will be calculated based on a fixed charge that varies by property type, and a variable charge based on property value.

Pensioners and veterans will also be eligible for $50 concessions on their homes, while single farm enterprises may be eligible for a fixed rate on separate parcels of land.

Clunes farmer Stuart Robinson (left), alongside Graeme Ford, Ian Terrill, John Henderson-Drife and Phillip Wilson all have many concerns about the proposed new levy. Picture by Lachlan Bence

urn:contentItem:6F2C-V393-RXB5-C1HM-00000-00Firefighters battle 30ha blaze in state's northeast2025-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisFirefighters battle 30ha blaze in state's northeast

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Abby Walter

Firefighters are responding to a blaze that covered 30ha at Maindample in the state's northeast.

A CFA spokesman said eight units responded to reports of the grassfire near the Maroondah Highway at The Paps Walk about 3.10pm.

"Units responded from Mansfield, Barjarg, Bonnie Doon, Maindample, Merton and Goughs Bay-Howes Creek," the spokesman said.

"Crews discovered a fire in steep country, spanning approximately 30ha."

The 'stay informed' message for Maindample, Howes Creek, Mansfield and Bonnie Doon warned smoke would be visible from nearby towns and roads.

There is no existing threat to communities but people should stay informed and monitor conditions.

People are also asked to keep roads clear for emergency services to respond.

The fire was declared under control about 8.15pm and three units remained on scene on Thursday morning patrolling the scene.

People can stay informed using the VicEmergency app, website or hotline, or tuning into ABC Radio, designated commercial and community radios or Sky News TV.

An advice message was also issued at 2pm for Lima East, Lima South, Nillahcootie and surrounds.

A tree was on fire on the Lightning Ridge Track within the Strathbogie State Forest.

A CFA spokeswoman said units responded from Benalla, Tatong, Lima South, Maindample and Swanpool.

She said the CFA deemed the incident under control shortly before 2.10pm and safe before 2.30pm.

"Aircraft and Forest Fire Management Victoria was on scene in support," she said.

urn:contentItem:6FDM-2HK3-RT17-21R7-00000-00Farmers to suffer unless government 'rights their wrongs'2025-03-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisNEWS2Farmers to suffer unless government 'rights their wrongs'

From page 1

ACM had previously revealed four south-west rural councils - Corangamite, Moyne, Glenelg and Southern Grampians - would collectively pay $17.8 million more in 2025-26 because of the new levy.

It found the 19 councils would pay an extra $69,907,940 in 2025-26, or $3,679,365 per council.

If that average holds across the rest of Victoria's 38 rural councils, they will have to pay an additional $139,815,880.

The current levy raises $1,033,000 per year, most of which goes towards running Fire Rescue Victoria (FRV), with the volunteer-driven Country Fire Association also getting a small portion.

The new ESVL will raise $1,649,000 in 2025-26, an increase of $616 million, which allow funding to flow to a broader range of services like the State Emergency Service, Triple Zero Victoria, the State Control Centre, Forest Fire Management Victoria and Emergency Recovery Victoria.

The bill to implement the new levy is currently before parliament and includes a $250 million "support package" for VICSES and CFA.

But it's worth noting that FRV's operating costs blew past $1.2 billion in 2023-24, and the government is still unable, or unwilling, to share how much the volunteer services will get.

The extra $616 million means the levy will require a 59 per cent increase statewide in 2025-26, but the RCV analysis showed rural councils would be hit with a 90 per cent average increase.

That means rural communities will have to pay 50 per cent more than the statewide average, or $3 for every $2 other Victorians pay.

The government has consistently declined to say whether this disproportionate hit to country Victoria will flow back to rural communities.

Victorian Nationals leader Danny O'Brien said the levy was an illegitimate revenue-raising exercise by the government.

"Victorians are being asked to pay double the amount for core government agencies that have always been paid for by the existing taxes we pay - it's double taxation, pure and simple. The government won't even release a breakdown of how much each of the agencies will receive from this massive new tax impost, and one has to ask why?"

The key change under the ESVL is an increase to the variable rate different property owners will pay on their annual rate bills.

Primary producers will be hit with 83 cents per $1000 of capital improved value, up from just under 29 cents currently. The RCV analysis showed this change meant farmers across the 18 councils would see their levy spike 154 per cent. The average farmer in some areas would see their levy triple.

Cr Amos said financial stress was already the second biggest driver of poor mental health for farmers.

"It's going to smash farm budgets, hurt local businesses and cause job losses in our towns and communities," he said.

RCV said it had written to Ms Symes and hoped to sit down with her to discuss the uneven impact of the levy.

"The ESVL isn't scheduled to come into force until July," Cr Amos said.

"There's still time for the Victorian government to acknowledge the inequities and unforeseen consequences of this new levy and make changes."

The state government plans to hit rural Victorians with 50 per cent more in levies than all other ratepayers.

urn:contentItem:6FGH-NY83-RT9B-454D-00000-00Allan govt forced to shelve 'bloody wrong' emergency services tax2025-04-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisAllan govt forced to shelve 'bloody wrong' emergency services tax

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Mitch Clarke

The Allan government has been forced to shelve its "bloody wrong" emergency services tax in an embarrassing backflip that will further ignite an already hostile campaign from firefighters, farmers and councils.

The levy - which has been referred to as a "dog of a tax" - will be debated in parliament's upper house on Thursday, but the government won't put the legislation to a vote, as originally planned, because it has failed to secure crossbench support.

Failure to pass the bill this week means the hostile campaign will now drag out across the federal election campaign, at a time when Jacinta Allan's brand is already causing huge issues for federal Labor.

And with parliament not resuming until April 30, it leaves Treasurer Jaclyn Symes with the prospect of a massive black hole in her first budget, which will be handed down on May 20.

The Allan government is banking on the increased tax, which replaces the existing Fire Services Levy, to rake in an extra $2bn over the forward estimates.

The Herald Sun understands that Ms Symes, who is also the leader of the government in the upper house, has so far been unable to wrangle any crossbench MPs to support the Bill.

Sources said the four upper house Greens MPs - who the government often looks to for support to pass legislation - had been asked by their federal counterparts to not support the Bill while the campaign was on.

Nationals leader and opposition emergency services spokesman Danny O'Brien said it was "great news" that the government didn't have the support to pass the bill this week.

"This Bill is a massive hit on Victorians during a cost of living crisis," he said.

"We now need the Labor government to realise this was a mistake and withdraw this unfair tax plan altogether."

But shadow treasurer James Newbury said Victorian's "won't be safe from this $2.1bn dollar new tax until Labor scraps the Bill from parliament".

"Labor's shelving of their great big new dog of a tax is only a stay of execution," he said.

Outside parliament on Thursday, Premier Jacinta Allan defended the tax grab and said an increase in natural disasters meant that emergency services needed to be appropriately funded.

"The SES have been calling for these changes," she said.

"Ultimately it's about providing the support to those thousands of volunteers who get out in the worst of circumstances to support us."

The government said expanding the tax will support a broader range of emergency services, including the SES, Triple Zero Victoria, State Control Centre, CFA and Forest Fire Management.

But the move has sparked a furious backlash from regional communities who have warned they will be disproportionately impacted by the tax.

The Herald Sun on Thursday revealed the peak body that represents rural councils - who will be forced to collect the levy from their communities - has urged the government to scrap the tax entirely and go back to the drawing board.

Council Watch president Dean Hurlston, who is a staunch critic of local government, wrote to all MPs this week urging them to reject the bill.

"It's rare that we defend them (councils), but in this case, you have left us no choice," he wrote.

"Councils are under a tight rate capping regime (rightly so), but it is in our view, an abusive relationship between the state and councils to treat them in this manner."

Victorian Chamber of Commerce and Industry chief executive Paul Guerra also called for the government to look at other ways to fund its volunteer emergency services.

"This is a short-sighted cash grab on the very industries that our state is renowned for and that keep Victoria moving. It will drive up food and other prices as the additional cost will be passed to consumers," he said.

urn:contentItem:6F1Y-06M3-RSH6-844S-00000-00Victoria braces for further fire threats2025-02-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisVictoria braces for further fire threats

Authorities are urging Victorians to stay alert as the risk of further fires remains high across the state.

Samantha Donovan: In Victoria, at least two houses have been destroyed as large bushfires continue to burn in the state's west. And as an oppressive heatwave rolls on, authorities are warning Victorians to stay alert as more fires could break out. David Estcourt has more.

David Estcourt: Dozens of tents hastily erected in the last 24 hours are buffeted by the wind at a base camp outside of Horsham in Victoria's north-west. The tents have been put up to hold about 250 crews from interstate for as long as five to six weeks. Barbara Bednarek is the base camp manager.

Barbara Bednarek: And they come in, stay here, then go out onto the fire ground and then come back. They get fed here, they can shower here, we have laundry facilities, everything that you need to be able to go out, fight a fire and then come back. They normally leave here at eight o'clock in the morning, so they get fed from six to eight, they get a briefing and then once they are briefed, they are then tasked. They are out of here by eight o'clock and then it depends on how long they are out before, they may come back at ten o'clock at night.

David Estcourt: Pitched on top of dry yellow grass in the hot sun, it's a snapshot into the sacrifice interstate firefighters make to be ready to fight blazes during this massive Victorian heatwave. Horsham, and many other places throughout Victoria, are bracing for further fires. Forest Fire Management Victoria says more than 8,000 lightning strikes were recorded across the state on Sunday. It sparked several spot fires. Two houses and two sheds were destroyed at Colignan, south of Mildura, in northwest Victoria on Sunday evening. And there are fears of more property losses to come as heatwave conditions continue across Victoria until Tuesday. Also at risk is Dunkeld, near the Grampians National Park, still recuperating from recent fires. Heather Funk, who operates a bed and breakfast in the Dunkeld area, says she has closed up while the risks continue.

Heather Funk: You just prepare for it, you stay close to home. We've got, like I say, we've done what we can to prepare. The communication this year has been magnificent from Forest Fire Management and the CFA, but it doesn't take the anxiety away from it because you're always worried about family and friends and when it gets this close, if it's not you that's impacted, it's probably somebody that you know.

David Estcourt: Hundreds of firefighters continue to battle blazes in three national parks in Victoria, including a new fire in the Otways in the state's southwest. Rick Nugent is Victoria's Emergency Management Commissioner.

Rick Nugent: In relation to the fires, we have current ongoing fires or fires that are still going in the Little Desert National Park, two fires in the Grampians National Park and also four new fires in the Great Otway National Park in the Otways. There were 114 new starts yesterday across private and public land, mostly started, ignited by dry lightning.

David Estcourt: This afternoon, a New South Wales fire crew vehicle was caught by the front and destroyed. Rick Nugent again.

Rick Nugent: It's the cumulative impact of heat that we are most concerned about, and in particular the elderly young people and those at risk and with medical conditions. Heat can cause illnesses such as cramps, heat exhaustion and heat stroke. And we do know that more people die from heat related events, heat waves, than they do from fires.

David Estcourt: Meanwhile, a bushfire burning in Snug Tiers, south of Hobart, was brought under control. But firefighting activities to extinguish the blaze are continuing. The fire, which has been burning for almost a week, had by Sunday afternoon burned through more than 480 hectares, with staff remaining on site in the coming days.

Samantha Donovan: David Estcourt.
