urn:contentItem:6F8J-ND93-RS6X-B19B-00000-00How the new ESVF tax will affect Victorian farmers2025-03-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisHow the new ESVF tax will affect Victorian farmers

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Peter Hunt

Farmers who are CFA and VicSES volunteers will be able to claim refunds of up to $4150 under the Allan Government's new Emergency Services Volunteer Fund tax, which comes into effect on July 1.

Treasurer Jaclyn Symes said farmers who were volunteers could apply for an exemption on paying the tax on property worth up to $5m in capital improved value.

However many farmers will still be worse off.

Under the current Fire Services Property Levy, farmers paid 28.7c per $1000 of their property's CIV this financial year.

But under the new ESVF property tax farmers will pay 83c/$1000 of CIV in 2025-26 - a three-fold increase.

It means a typical $15m Victorian farm, which paid $4305 in FSPL levies this financial year, faces paying $12,450 in 2025-26.

If that same property owner is a CFA or VicSES volunteer they can apply to the State Revenue Office for a maximum rebate of $4150, which still leaves them with an ESVF tax bill of $8300 - almost twice what they paid under the FSPL.

Victorian Farmers Federation president and CFA volunteer Brett Hosking said triple the levy would hurt all Victorians.

As for the rebate, Mr Hosking said: "It's just wrong for many volunteers to be still funding a service they have to provide."

Volunteer Fire Brigades Victoria chief executive Adam Barnett said the government was yet to consult the group's members, which was a statutory obligation.

Even with the rebate, Mr Barnett said volunteers were very concerned about the impact of the new tax on their communities.

"People can't afford it and the government has underestimated the pain communities are feeling," he said.

Under the FSPL the government generated $1.033bn in 2024-25 levy revenue, but the ESVF will lift its tax take to $1.649bn in 2025-26 and $1.8bn in 2026-27.

However just $50m of the $616m in extra revenue the government gains in the new financial year will go towards supporting CFA, VicSES, Surf Live Saving Victoria and community coast guard volunteers.

Instead the ESVF legislation, introduced to parliament this week, opens the door for the government to use most of the extra cash for public servants' wages.

The Bill states that ESVF funding can be used to fund up to 95 per cent of the following government agency budgets:

Triple-0 Victoria, which cost $343m to run in 2023-24.

STATE Control Centre, which budget papers show cost about $11m a year to run.

EMERGENCY Recovery Victoria (budget not public).

EMERGENCY Management Victoria (budget not public).

EMERGENCY Alert Program - automatic emergency warning SMSs (budget not public).

EMERGENCY Management Operational Communication Program (budget not public).

FOREST Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) and its support functions within the Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action (budget not public).

Ms Symes said: "We're making sure our emergency services have the sustainable funding and equipment they need to keep Victorians safe and to recover from natural disasters."

urn:contentItem:6DY5-WVR3-RRW4-41DY-00000-00Iconic Grampians Tourist Road to reopen in time for long weekend2025-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisIconic Grampians Tourist Road to reopen in time for long weekendBen Fraser

The picturesque road from Dunkeld to Halls Gap opens on January 24.

The iconic Grampians Road will reopen just in time for the Australia Day long weekend.

Forest Fire Management Victoria announced the road connecting Dunkeld to Halls Gap will be accessible from Friday, January 24, 2025, from 10am.

Tourists can now access several significant routes and sites, including Victoria Valley Road, Wonderland walks north of the Pinnacle, and Reeds Lookout.

"We're delighted to be welcoming people back to popular sites like the Pinnacle Walk, Reeds Lookout and other unaffected areas of the park," Incident Controller Les Vearing said.

"This reopening will be significant for these towns, including Halls Gap and Dunkeld, and they look forward to welcoming visitors this long weekend."

Ms Vearing said the decision was made by authorities following the bushfire response from FFMVic, CFA and other agencies to the Yarram Gap Road bushfire started in the Grampians National Park on December 17, 2024.

Visitors can access the Pinnacle Walk in the Wonderland Range from Halls Gap and Wonderland carpark.

However, all walking tracks south of the Pinnacle, including those in the Sundial area, remain closed.

Motorists should note that other park access roads and walking tracks in the fire-impacted area, including Silverband Road, Yarram Gap Road and Mt William Road, remain closed.

Regional Roads Victoria assessed and repaired around 45km of the Grampians Tourist Road following the fire.

Repairs will continue along the road over the coming months.

For full details, visit https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/coc-listing?status=Closed+Areas or Brambuk the National Park and Cultural Centre in Halls Gap.

The Grampians Tourist Road is set to reopen on Friday, January 24. File picture

urn:contentItem:6F29-16B3-RSH5-H4R1-00000-00Fireys on red alert2025-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Fireys on red alertRachel Simmonds

Six hundred firefighters are stationed at the Grampians ahead of continued hot weather this week, while a new fire threatens the Otways.

Hot weather and dry lightning sparked new fires and caused established fires to spread since Saturday, as VicEmergency issued 103 warnings and 27 emergency alerts within 24 hours.

Major fires at the Grampians from Mooralla to Mount William, which threatened private properties, spanned more than 100,000ha and had started connecting.

The Bureau of Meteorology reported more than 100,000 lightning strikes during the storm conditions on Sunday, and SAID 50,000 hit land, which ignited most of the 114 new fire starts.

Emergency Management Victoria commissioner Rick Nugent said a fire at Nangiloc, Mildura, destroyed two homes on Sunday. At the Little Desert National Park, a firefighting vehicle caught fire and had been "totally destroyed", but the three firefighters inside were able to escape.

The Little Desert National Park fire spread towards Goroke on Monday, burning into agricultural land with no reports of any losses. The Little Desert fire had grown to 83,556ha.

Dimboola farmer and Antwerp brigade member Stu Walker said he felt reasonably confident in the containment lines ahead of this week.

"The dry lightning is the wildcard," he said. "We had a huge lightning storm here (on Monday) with little rain." Mr Walker joined the Tarranyurk brigade truck last week, when the fire started. "It was like a scene from an apocalypse really, the way it came in. All the trees were on fire, we couldn't see with the smoke, it was mayhem. We were super lucky the wind changed when it did." Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said there had been 15,000-20,000ha of backburning to protect communities.

"We've always got to remember an outbuilding could have $2m worth of farming equipment in it. That risk is there, this is why we ask community members to stay very much alert," he said. Marranatwa residents were under an evacuation warning on Tuesday.
